bindsSigmaFactor_name: RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS
note: σ70 is the sigma factor principally responsible for the alkA transcription. However alkA is highly dependent on alternative factor σ38 (RpoS) during the stationary phase. In contrast, the transcription factor Ada in its methylated state negatively regulates σ38-dependent transcription |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC00635]|. EσS is more efficient than Eσ70 in carrying out transcription from the alkA promoter in the absence of Ada (Ada is a repressor for EσS) |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC00635]|.

note: Based on ChIP-microarray analysis, it was shown that StpA binds to the promoter region in appYp2 |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC27241][RDBECOLIPRC10718]|. qRT-PCR revealed a strong 75-fold repression of appY by H-NS and more than 1,000-fold repression by H-NS/StpA |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC18945]|. Transcription directed across H-NS binding regions relieves H-NS-mediated (and H-NS/StpA-mediated) repression of promoters such as proVp3, pdeLp3, and appYp2, and there is a correlation between transcription across the H-NS-bound region and derepression where RNA polymerase is able to remodel the H-NS complex and/or dislodge H-NS from the DNA and thus relieve repression |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC18945]|.

note: argXp promoter activity is inhibited by the stringent response in vivo |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC25105]|. The transcription of the argXp promoter, also called the argTp promoter, is reduced by guanosine tetraphosphate (ppGpp), which modifies the RNA polymerase that forms an inactive promoter complex |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC06658], [RDBECOLIPRC01644]|. Individually, DksA and ppGpp activate and inhibit, respectively, the transcription started from the argX promoter (argXp). On the other hand, argXp also is regulated negatively by DksA, and this response occurs in the absence of ppGpp |CITS:[ 27915292]|.
citations_evidence_publication: The evidence 'RNA polymerase footprinting' linked to the reference PMID:15780938, The evidence 'Transcription initiation mapping' linked to the reference PMID:15780938, The evidence 'Inferred from mutant phenotype' linked to the reference PMID:15780938

note: A total of 554 promoter regions from Escherichia coli were aligned in order to analyze their sequence similarities. |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC04467]| focused on conservation, patterns, similarities, and differences between promoters with or without an extended -10 5'-TG-3' element and other conserved elements. They experimentally showed that, for several naturally occurring extended -10 promoters, the 5'-TRTG-3' motif is an important determinant for promoter activity. Eleven promoters were selected for further experimental study. Of those, the seven most active (aroF > ompF > envA > purFp1 > purEF > purMN > gyrA) were investigated for the contribution of the extended -10 motif by changing the 5'-TG-3' element. Promoters with poor matches to the -10 and -35 consensus hexamers are more dependent on the 5'-TG-3' motif, and this plays a similar role on different promoters. The dinucleotide at -17 and -16 in aroFp results in similar patterns of activity, suggesting that these bases play a similar role on different promoters |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC04467]|.

note: There are two codBA transcriptional start positions, G7 and A8, relative to the -10 box. note: Of the transcriptional start site of this promoter, an AT-rich upstream activation sequence was determined that is required for transcriptional activation during entry into stationary phase; it is positioned between -98 and -54 with respect to the transcriptional start point. Crl is a new thermosensor identified in the Escherichia coli RpoS regulon which interacts directly with σS, promoting the binding of EσS to the csgBp promoter |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC05474]|.

note: Of the transcriptional start site of this promoter, an AT-rich upstream activation sequence was determined that is required for transcriptional activation during entry into stationary phase; it is positioned between -98 and -54 with respect to the transcriptional start point. There are two transcripts in the csgBA operon; one primary transcript is initiated from the csgB promoter, which is differentially degraded to give a shorter transcript corresponding to the csgA gene. Crl is a new thermosensor identified in the Escherichia coli RpoS regulon which interacts directly with σS, promoting the binding of EσS to the csgBp promoter |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC05474]|.

note: 554 promoter regions from Escherichia coli were aligned in order to analyze their sequence similarities. Mitchell et al. (2003) |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC04467]| focused on conservation, patterns, similarities, and differences between promoters with or without an extended -10 5'-TG-3' element and other conserved elements. They experimentally showed that, for several naturally occurring extended -10 promoters, the 5'-TRTG-3' motif is an important determinant for promoter activity. Eleven promoters were selected for further experimental study. Of those, the seven most active (aroF > ompF > envA > purFp1 > purEF > purMN > gyrA) were investigated about the contribution of the extended -10 motif by changing the 5'-TG-3'. Promoters with poor matches to the -10 and -35 consensus hexamers are more dependent on the 5'-TG-3' motif, and this plays a similar role on different promoters. The dinucleotide at -17 and -16 in aroFp results in similar patterns of activity, suggesting that these bases play a similar role on different promoters |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC04467]|.

note: cyaRp could be transcribed from EσE, since cyaR expression is up-regulated in response to an increase in the activity of σE. Furthermore, a small group of σE-regulated factors is also regulated by σ70. Another issue is the fact that the -10 and -35 boxes of cyaR match with the ecfFp2 boxes, which are under control of σE. In addition, cyaRp contains in the upstream region an AU-rich region which may have a role in recognition of the alternative RNA polymerases |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC10196]|.

note: This is the +1 in induced cells; in uninduced cells transcription starts 5 bp dowstream: GATTAGA-(here). Several regions with significant similarity to known σ70 promoter sequences were found. Previous genetic studies identified a dadR gene as a cis-acting regulatory region of the dad operon. Therefore, the dadR region may contain promoter and regulatory sequences of the dad operon. The DNA fragment of about 260 bp preceding dadA should correspond to dadR.

note: Zaslaver et al. demonstrated in 2006, by means of a library of fluorescent transcription fusions, that this promoter can be transcribed in vitro |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08095]|. There are two transcription start sites (TSSs) for the yafN promoter. Here we associated the TTS more upstream to this promoter. In addition, Christensen-Dalsgaard et al. (2009) showed -10 and -35 boxes which are far from the normal position |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC11425]|. However, the -10 box associated with the yafN promoter also shows an unusual distance |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC11623]|.

bindsSigmaFactor_name: RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS
note: Results suggest that the dps promoter is recognized by both the σ70 holoenzyme and σS holoenzyme, since OxyR acts on σ70, and in addition the starts of the OxyR-dependent and the σS-dependent transcripts are identical. This promoter displays an unusual form of regulation. If cells are treated with hydrogen peroxide during exponential growth, dps transcription is induced by OxyR, which activates σ70 RNA polymerase. Surprisingly, the same promoter is also activated by IHF and σS at the onset of the stationary phase. It is assumed that both OxyR and IHF bind upstream of the dps promoter and that the mechanisms of activation act independently of each other. The promoter has a a sequence that conforms to the consensus -10, but no obvious -35 sequence is present. Possibly, the dps promoter is not ideally bound by either holoenzyme, leading to the need for IHF to enhance the binding of σS RNA polymerase and of OxyR to enhance the binding of σ70 RNA polymerase. The dpS gene is positively regulated by RpoS in stationary phase, and it is mainly controlled at the level of transcription |CITS: [ 11157932 ]|. The effect by RpoS is likely indirect and might be mediated by an intermediate regulator that itself is directly regulated by RpoS. Phadtare et al. (2001) found that CspC and CspE upregulate the expression of dps by regulating the expression of RpoS itself |CITS: [ 11157932 ]|. Fis and H-NS control σ factor selection at the dps promoter |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC09990]|. This promoter appears to be activated during σE induction. It is induced during the first 5 minutes following σE induction, decreased from 5 to 10 minutes, induced from 10 to 15 minutes, and decreased from 15 to 20 minutes |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC20476]|.

note: The DksA protein binds directly to RNA polymerase, destabilizing transcription complexes and increasing the effect of the alarmone ppGpp on transcription initiation |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC08119]|. DksA together with ppGpp is required for transcription inhibition of the dusBp (Pfis) promoter in mid-log and late-log growth phases and in stationary phase |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC08119]|. dusBp, also known as fisp, is one of the few known promoters that initiates transcription predominantly with CTP |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC03459]|, which is a feature strongly conserved in dusBp (fisp) in other bacteria |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC05295]|.

note: The expression of the eptB gene is induced primarily by σ70, and it is totally repressed by MgrR |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC14993]|. note: The fimAp promoter is located in a region that is part of a 314-bp invertible region whose inversion is necessary to activate ("on" orientation) or inactivate (" off" orientation) the transcription of the fimAICDFGH operon|CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC18572][RDBECOLIPRC24708]|. The sequence is shown in the off orientation in the database, and therefore the -10 and -35 boxes are located downstream of the transcriptional start site (TSS), and their sequences are shown in the inverted direction |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC18572][RDBECOLIPRC24708]|. When the region is inverted, the boxes are located in the correct position (upstream of the TSS) and correct orientation (-10 box TATGAT, -35 box TTGAGA) to be functional and activate the fim operon |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC18572][RDBECOLIPRC24708]|. fimA transcription is regulated by the growth phase. and its repression requires the alternative σ factor, RpoS, during entry to stationary phase. Although the mechanism by which RpoS achieves negative control is unknown, it is possible that the effect on fimA is exerted indirectly |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC28008]| .

note: Baljinder et al. showed that NanR, NagC, and IHF activate fimBgene expression, but they could not determine which of the three promoters (fimBp1, fimBp2, fimBp3) is affected |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC08717] [RDBECOLIPRC06290]|, and none could demonstrate which is the transcription activation mechanism. They concluded that the activation from NagC and IHF could be indirect, altering the DNA structure of the intergenic region between fimB and nanC. Another possibility of activating the system is through direct contact of NagC with RNA polymerase |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC08717] [RDBECOLIPRC06290]|. There are three potential transcription start sites. Transcription starting from two of the sites (P1 and P2) would produce an mRNA that approximates the transcript size of fimB previously detected by Northern blot hybridizations.

note: Baljinder et al. showed that NanR, NagC, and IHF activate fimB gene expression, but they could not determine which of the three promoters (fimBp1, fimBp2, or fimBp3) is affected |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC08717][RDBECOLIPRC06290]|, and none could demonstrate which is the transcription activation mechanism. They concluded that the activation from NagC and IHF could be indirect, altering the DNA structure of the intergenic region between fimB and nanC. Another possibility of activating the system is through direct contact of NagC with RNA polymerase |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC08717][RDBECOLIPRC06290]|. There are three potential transcription start sites. Transcription starting from two of the sites (P1 and P2) would produce an mRNA that approximates the transcript size of fimB previously detected by Northern blot hybridizations. On the other hand, a σ32-dependent promoter was suggested to be located upstream of fimB |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC08130]|, but it is unknown whether this promoter is the same as fimBp2 .

bindsSigmaFactor_name: RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA, RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA, RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA
note: The sequence of this promoter has been defined, by computational analyses, from the consensus sequence of the σ28 (σF) promoters: TAAAGTTT in the -35 box and GCCGATAA in the -10 box |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC02484],[RDBECOLIPRC01630], [RDBECOLIPRC00714]|. Therefore, we assigned a putative transcription start site for this promoter based on the observation that the majority of the σ28 promoters, determined experimentally, present an important -10 motif (5'-CGA-3') at the positions -12 to -10 and a distance of 6 nucleotides between the transcription start site and the -10 box |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08081], [RDBECOLIPRC08301], [RDBECOLIPRC02484]|. Kundu et al. showed in 1997 that transcription of flgK is highly dependent on alternative sigma factor σF and can be transcribed by RNA polymerase σ28 in vitro |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC28204]|. In a cell-free expression system, the activation of flgK was strongly increased in the presence of σ28 and slightly activated by FlhDC |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC17807]|.

bindsSigmaFactor_name: RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA, RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA, RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA, RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA
note: The sequence of this promoter has been defined, by computational analyses, from the consensus sequence of the σ<sup>28</sup> (σ<sup>F</sup>)  promoters TAAAGTTT in the -35 box and GCCGATAA in the -10 box |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC02484][RDBECOLIPRC20981][RDBECOLIPRC00714]|.  Thus, we assigned a putative transcription start site for this promoter based on the observation that the majority of the σ<sup>28</sup> promoters, determined experimentally, present an important -10 motif (5'-CGA-3') at the -12 to -10 positions and a distance of 6 nucleotides between the transcription start site and the -10 box  |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08081][RDBECOLIPRC08301][RDBECOLIPRC02484]|.  Kundu et al. showed in 1997 that transcription offliCis highly dependent on alternative factor σ<sup>28</sup>, encoded by the fliA gene |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC28204]|, but it has been observed that fliA gene expression is not a guarantee that fliCp is activated. Rather, spontaneous on-off switching occurs in the promoter, and this behavior appears to be dependent on FlgM, the inhibitor of σ<sup>28</sup> |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC20509]|.

note: The sequence of this promoter has been defined, by computational analyses, from the consensus sequence of the σ28 (σF) promoters: TAAAGTTT in the -35 box and GCCGATAA in the -10 box |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC02484]|. Therefore, we assigned a putative transcription start site for this promoter based on the observation that the majority of the σ28 promoters, determined experimentally, present an important -10 motif (5'-CGA-3') at the positions -12 to -10 and a distance of 6 nucleotides between the transcription start site and the -10 box |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08081], [RDBECOLIPRC08301], [RDBECOLIPRC02484]|. Ide et al. showed in 1997 that transcription of flxA is highly dependent on alternative factor σF |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC28457]|. The transcription expression level was examined in a fliA mutant background.

note: Based on Northern blotting analysis, the gadEp2 (T2 mRNA) promoter was identified by Sayed and Foster in 2009 |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC10819]|. However, using different techniques, such as RNase-deficient, translational funtions, luciferase assay, and RT-PCR, it was determined that the 5'end at -324 (T2 mRNA) was monophosphoryled; it was also shown that T2 mRNA was generated from T3 mRNA via RNA processing, so that gadEp2 was removed |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC15796]|.

note: Three alternative 5' ends of GadY (105, 90, and 59 nucleotides) were identified by primer extension. gadY (90) and gadY (59) are believed to be processed forms of the full-length 105-nucleotide transcript due to the fact that the expression of all three forms was eliminated when Opdyke et al. (2004) mutated the promoter of the full-length RNA.

bindsSigmaFactor_name: RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoD, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoD
note: The galETKM operon is transcribed from three promoters, galEp1, galEp2, and galEp3. galEp2 is predominantly expressed when cAMP-CRP is absent, leading to expression of the galE gene and very little galK (natural polarity) |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12411]|. On the other hand, in the presence of cAMP-CRP, the galEp1 promoter leads to equimolar expression of all the structural genes, while galEp2 transcription is inhibited |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC23083][RDBECOLIPRC14285][RDBECOLIPRC12411]|. It appears that the galEp2 transcript may serve anabolic requirements, while galEp1 may provide for catabolism of D-galactose as a carbon source |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12411]|. galEp1 is the main promoter during the exponential growth phase, since it produces 70% of total galE transcripts |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12872]|. galEp1 transcription is downregulated earlier than galEp2 transcription at the end of the exponential growth phase |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12872]|. This promoter has an extended -10 region. GalR, which mediates formation of the DNA loop on galEp1, was less efficient in repressing galEp1 transcription when RNA polymerase was bound to the -10 and -35 elements concomitantly |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC14465]|. Promoters that lack specific -35 element recognition allow decoupling of local chromosome structure from transcription initiation |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC14465]|.

note: The galETKM operon is transcribed from three promoters, galEp1, galEp2, and galEp3. galEp2 is predominantly expressed when cAMP-CRP is absent, leading to expression of the galE gene and very little galK (natural polarity) |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12411]|. On the other hand, in the presence of cAMP-CRP, the galEp1 promoter leads to equimolar expression of all the structural genes, while galEp2 transcription is inhibited |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC23083][RDBECOLIPRC14285][RDBECOLIPRC12411]|. It appears that the galEp2 transcript may serve anabolic requirements, while galEp1 may provide for catabolism of D-galactose as a carbon source |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12411]|. Repression of galEp2 requires tetramerization of GalR, which is mediated by HU forming a complex called a repressome |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC10537] |and references therein|. galEp2 is the main promoter during stationary phase, since it produces 70% of the total galE transcripts |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12872]|. galEp1 transcription is downregulated earlier than galEp2 transcription at the end of the exponential growth phase |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12872]|.

note: The galETKM operon is transcribed from three promoters, galEp1, galEp2, and galEp3. galEp2 is predominantly expressed when cAMP-CRP is absent, leading to expression of the galE gene and very little galK (natural polarity) |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12411]|. On the other hand, in the presence of cAMP-CRP, the galEp1 promoter leads to equimolar expression of all the structural genes, while galEp2 transcription is inhibited |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC23083][RDBECOLIPRC14285][RDBECOLIPRC12411]|. It appears that the galEp2 transcript may serve anabolic requirements, while galEp1 may provide for catabolism of D-galactose as a carbon source |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12411]|. Repression of galEp2 requires tetramerization of GalR, which is mediated by HU forming a complex called a repressome |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC10537] |and references therein|. galEp2 is the main promoter during stationary phase, since it produces 70% of the total galE transcripts |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12872]|. galEp1 transcription is downregulated earlier than galEp2 transcription at the end of the exponential growth phase |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12872]|.

bindsSigmaFactor_name: RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS
note: The galETKM operon is transcribed from three promoters, galEp1, galEp2, and galEp3. galEp2 is predominantly expressed when cAMP-CRP is absent, leading to expression of the galE gene and very little galK (natural polarity) |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12411]|. On the other hand, in the presence of cAMP-CRP, the galEp1 promoter leads to equimolar expression of all the structural genes, while galEp2 transcription is inhibited |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC23083][RDBECOLIPRC14285][RDBECOLIPRC12411]|. It appears that the galEp2 transcript may serve anabolic requirements, while galEp1 may provide for catabolism of D-galactose as a carbon source |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12411]|. galEp1 is the main promoter during the exponential growth phase, since it produces 70% of total galE transcripts |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12872]|. galEp1 transcription is downregulated earlier than galEp2 transcription at the end of the exponential growth phase |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12872]|. This promoter has an extended -10 region. GalR, which mediates formation of the DNA loop on galEp1, was less efficient in repressing galEp1 transcription when RNA polymerase was bound to the -10 and -35 elements concomitantly |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC14465]|. Promoters that lack specific -35 element recognition allow decoupling of local chromosome structure from transcription initiation |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC14465]|.

note: Based on mutational analysis, a short sequence, up to 7 bp downstream of the -10 region, is involved in the stringent response of the rnpB promoter |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC10260]|. Primer extension analysis shows that rnpBp initiates not only at the +1 G position (70% efficiency) |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC24652][RDBECOLIPRC15854]| but also at the -1 C position (30% efficiency) |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC10260]|.

note: The activity of gatYp promoter appears to be decreased in the presence of σE. It is repressed during the first 5 minutes following σE induction and decreased from 5 to 10 minutes and from 10 to 20 minutes after induction of the σ factor |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC20476]|. This promoter appears to have more transcriptional sites at positions 2177230/1/2/3, as determined by high-throughput screening of maps of promoters |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC20476]|.

note: The gclp promoter is activated in the presence of glyoxylate and repressed in the presence of allantoin |CITS:[ 20964794]|. Single-cell assays show that this promoter is heterogeneously activated by glyoxylate in the cells within the same culture. In some cells the promoter is activated to a greater extent than in others; in approximately 30% of the cells in a given culture the promoter is not activated |CITS:[ 20964794]|.

note: Two transcriptional start sites were mapped in the upstream regulatory region of glgS. The glgSp1 transcript was absent in a cya mutant. Two shorter fragments visible for the wild type and the rpoS mutant might be incompletely synthesized reverse transcripts, but they might also represent genuine transcriptional start sites indicative of a third and fourth promoter. If so, these promoters would be dependent on cAMP, since these transcripts are not found in the cya strain. glgSp1 is inactive in a cya background. It is preceded by a putative CRP-binding site that is appropriately located and exhibits good homology to the consensus, which probably compensates for the absence of a -35 site and the poor homology of the -10 site to the σ70 consensus |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC04652]|.

note: Two transcriptional start sites were mapped in the upstream regulatory region of glgS. An rpoS mutant did not synthesize the glgSp2 transcript. Two shorter fragments visible for the wild type and the rpoS mutant might be incompletely synthesized reverse transcripts, but they might also represent genuine transcriptional start sites, indicative of a third and fourth promoter. If so, these promoters would be dependent on cAMP, since these transcripts are not found in the cya strain. glgSp2 is inactive in a rpoS background. Although transcription from glgSp2 requires σS, this promoter does not show similarity to the putative consensus derived from the comparison of the katE, xthA, and bolA promoters. This indicates that either this latter group of promoters or glgSp2 are under the indirect control of RpoS, involving an unknown secondary regulatory protein |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC04652]|.

note: The transcription of the glmZ gene starts at σ54-dependent promoters in several enterobacterial species, but this is not the case for Escherichia coli, where σ70 promotes the transcription of the gene |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12443][RDBECOLIPRC11504]|. In E. coli, the transcription of the glmY gene, which is homologous to glmZ, is activated by GlrR and by IHF |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12443][RDBECOLIPRC11504]|. Putative sequences to bind these proteins were found upstream of glmZ homologues containing a σ54-dependent promoter in other species, but they were not found in E. coli |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12443][RDBECOLIPRC11504]|.

note: This promoter presents two transcription initiations, with the following absolute positions: 3326875 and 3326874 |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC07417]|. Two-thirds of greA transcripts terminate within the leader region, and the remaining third comprises greA mRNA. This is because the greA leader region has an unusual intrinsic terminator that produces two clusters of small RNA chains called GraL, which originate from two overlapping upstream greAp1 and greAp2 promoters |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC11675]|. The array of short transcripts could be associated with paused or arrested transcripts |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC11675]|.

note: The Escherichia coli guaB promoter (PguaB) regulates transcription of the guaBA operon, encoding GuaB and GuaA, which are required for the de novo synthesis of GMP. Between the guaB and guaA genes exists a 68-bp intercistronic region that contains a palindromic sequence and could form a possible ρ-independent terminator, but the effect of this possible hairpin loop should be modest over the expression of the guaB gene |CITS [RDBECOLIPRC21920]|. In 1977, Fukumaki et al. showed that the transcription of the guaA gene can be dependent on a secondary promoter located within the guaB gene, but the precise position was not located |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC20802]|. Evidence to demonstrate this was obtained by using a fago lambda-pguaA transducing phage |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC20802]|. The activity of guaBp is subject to growth rate-dependent control (GRDC), that is, the activity of guaBp increases as a function of the cellular growth rate |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC27553][RDBECOLIPRC09682][RDBECOLIPRC10088]|. Two elements are required for this regulation, an UP element, located between -59 and -38 relative to the guaB transcriptional start site |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC09682]|, and a binding site for cAMP-CRP, located over 100 bp upstream of the transcription start site. cAMP-CRP, bound to this upstream site, downregulates guaBp. Downregulation is influenced by the growth rate and not by the carbon source |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC11272]|. The UP element, which is also required for GRDC, contains two independent subsites that are able to activate transcription independently. It stimulates guaBA transcription ~8- to 10-fold both in vivo and in vitro, and this activity requires the C-terminal domain of the RNA polymerase α-subunit |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC09682]|. The mechanism by which cAMP-CRP together with the UP element regulate transcription in a growth rate-dependent manner is not yet clear. Based on deletion analysis, purified proteins of FIS, and multiple in vitro transcription assays, Husnain and Thomas (2008) |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC10088]| proved that the putative FIS-binding sites (-126, -109, -92, and -76) located upstream of the guaBp core elements are not functional, since FIS does not bind in these sites, and they were removed from EcoCyc. Binding of FIS to sites FIS I, II, and III (-11, +8, and +29, respectively), identified by Husnain and Thomas (2008), represses transcription from guaBA ~8- to 10-fold in vitro but not in vivo |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC10088]|. guaBp is repressed by PurR, and the binding site for PurR overlaps the core promoter |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC11272][RDBECOLIPRC27553]|. Expression of guaB is also repressed by DnaA in vivo. A consensus binding site, located approximately 200 bp downstream from the translation initiation codon, is required for DnaA-mediated repression at guaBp |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC27683][RDBECOLIPRC08887]|. The role of a second, nonconsensus DnaA site overlapping the guaB promoter is not yet clear. In addition, guaBp carries a GC-rich discriminator |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC18780]|. Neither Fis nor DnaA or PurR is required for GRDC of guaBp |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC10088][RDBECOLIPRC11272]|.

note: A total of 554 promoter regions from Escherichia coli were aligned in order to analyze their sequence similarities. Mitchell et al. (2003) |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC04467]| focused on conservation, patterns, similarities, and differences between promoters with or without an extended -10 5'-TG-3' element and other conserved elements. They experimentally show that, for several naturally occurring extended -10 promoters, the 5'-TRTG-3' motif is an important determinant for promoter activity. Eleven promoters were selected for further experimental study. Of those, the seven most active (aroF > ompF > envA > purFp1 > purEF > purMN > gyrA) were investigated for the contribution of the extended -10 motif by changing the 5'-TG-3' motif. Promoters with poor matches to the -10 and -35 consensus hexamers are more dependent on the 5'-TG-3' motif, and this plays a similar role on different promoters. The dinucleotide at -17 and -16 in aroFp results in similar patterns of activity, suggesting that these bases play a similar role for different promoters |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC04467]|.

The authors suggested that mutation/deletion studies will allow better definition of its position |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC15827]|.

note: The sequence of this promoter has been defined, by computational analyses, from the consensus sequence of the σ<sup>28</sup> (σ<sup>F</sup>)  promoters: TAAAGTTT in the -35 box and GCCGATAA in the -10 box |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08301]|. Thus, we assigned a putative transcription start site for this promoter based on the observation that the majority of the σ<sup>28</sup> promoters, determined experimentally, present an important -10 motif (5'-CGA-3') at the positions -12 to -10 and a distance of 6 nucleotides between the transcription start site and the -10 box  |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08081], [RDBECOLIPRC08301], [RDBECOLIPRC02484]|.

note: The activity of this promoter appears to be decreased in the presence of σE. It is repressed during the first 5 minutes following σE induction and decreased from 5 to 10 minutes and from 10 to 20 minutes after induction of the σ factor |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC20476]|. Single-cell assays have shown that the hupAp promoter is heterogeneously activated in cells within the same culture. In some cells the promoter is activated to a greater extent than in others; in approximately 20% of the cells in a given culture the promoter is not activated |CITS:[ 20964794]|.

note: iraDp1 is present during entry into stationary phase but not in exponential phase |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC11482]|. RelA or SpoT is required during the transition to stationary phase of iraDp1. ppGpp production is primarily RelA dependent in growing cells but switches to more balanced production by both RelA and SpoT in the late exponential phase |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC11482]|. This promoter has an AT-rich "discriminator" region downstream of the -10 sequence which could be involved with direct positive regulation by ppGpp |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC11482]|. The iraDp1 promoter appears to be induced by the presence of the regulator SspA |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC30949]|.

note: iraDp2 is present under both entry into stationary phase and during exponential phase |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC11482]|. This promoter becomes (p)ppGpp independent during the stationary phase, but it requires RelA predominantly during exponential growth |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC11482]|. The iraDp2 promoter appears to be induced by the presence of the replication inhibitor azidothymidine (AZT) or the presence of the regulator SspA |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC30949]|. In contrast, SspA appears to inhibit the induction of the promoter caused by AZT when they are together |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC30949]|.

note: lac operon expression was studied during diauxic shift; although it was supposed to be under σS control (as σS is the main sigma factor for cell adaptation during this change), no σS site has been found in this promoter, nor is there a reported correlation of lac expression with σS WT or deleted |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC29315]|. Insulation of the lac promoter was tested by Sasson et al. in 2012 |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC14231]|. In that study, activators showed better insulation at high expression levels and repressors showed better insulation at low expression levels, following Savageau's rule, in which Escherichia coli genes that are needed often in the natural environment tend to be regulated by activators and those genes that are rarely needed are regulated by repressors |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC22557][RDBECOLIPRC14231]|.

note: The lptAp1 promoter depends on σ<sup>E</sup> for its activity; however, this promoter is not activated under all stress conditions that activate σ<sup>E</sup>, although the promoter is activated by a very specific stress condition that induces modifications in lipopolysaccharide (LPS) composition and biogenesis |CITS:[ 21402154]|. For that, it is possible that at least an additional transcription factor, whose activity is affected by LPS stress,  is also involved in the regulation of the lptAp1 promoter |CITS:[ 21402154]|.

note: Based on mutations of the -10 and -35 boxes of the malI promoter, Lloyd et al. (2009) |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC10598]| showed that the promoter activity is decreased by mutations in both boxes. On the other hand, these investigators used site-directed mutagenesis at the -10 element identified by Reidl et al. (1989) and found this mutation had very little effect on malI promoter activity. All this suggests that the transcription start identified by Lloyd et al. (2009) must be 5 bp upstream from that determined experimentally by Reidl et al. (1989) |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC17497]|.

On the other hand, the other promoters transcribing infBp mapped in the same nucleotide in a strain derived from K-12 as in MRE600 |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC20028]|.

note: A mutation in the rpoE gene was created, and it was observed that this mutation causes inactivation of the micAp promoter |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC08320]|. bindsSigmaFactor_name: RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA, RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA, RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA, RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA, RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA
note: The sequence of this promoter has been defined, by computational analyses, from the consensus sequence of the σ28 (σF) promoters: TAAAGTTT in the ?35 box and GCCGATAA in the -10 box |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08301]|. Therefore, we assigned a putative transcription start site for this promoter based on the observation that the majority of the σ28 promoters, determined experimentally, present an important -10 motif (5'-CGA-3') at the positions -12 to -10 and a distance of 6 nucleotides between the transcription start site and the -10 box |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08081], [RDBECOLIPRC08301], [RDBECOLIPRC02484]|. Yu et al. showed in 2006 that transcription of modA is highly dependent on alternative factor σF and can be transcribed by RNA polymerase σ28 in vitro |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08301]|.

bindsSigmaFactor_name: RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA, RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA, RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA
note: The sequence of this promoter has been defined, by computational analyses, from the consensus sequence of the σ28 (σF) promoters TAAAGTTT in the -35 box and GCCGATAA in the -10 box |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC02484][RDBECOLIPRC01630][RDBECOLIPRC00714]|. Therefore, we assigned a putative transcription start site for this promoter based on the observation that the majority of the σ28 promoters, determined experimentally, present an important -10 motif (5'-CGA-3') at the positions -12 to -10 and a distance of 6 nucleotides between the transcription start site and the -10 box |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC08081][RDBECOLIPRC08301][RDBECOLIPRC02484]|. The motAp promoter is an intragenic promoter controlled by FliA, which is inside the flhC gene. The FliA promoter within the flhC gene constrains evolution of the FlhC amino acid sequence. |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC18971]|. Although FlhC has two amino acids (Ala177 and Asp178) overlapping the -10 region, which are highly conserved among γ-proteobacteria, Asp178 is not required for FlhC function |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC18971]|. The Ala-Asp motif is conserved due to selective pressure on the motA promoter, rather than on the amino acids themselves |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC18971]|. motAp, the promoter within the flhC gene, is the most highly conserved of all FliA promoters |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC18971]|.

note: 554 promoter regions from Escherichia coli were aligned in order to analyze their sequence similarities. Mitchell et al. (2003) |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC04467]| focused on conservation, patterns, similarities, and differences between promoters with or without an extended -10 5'-TG-3' element and other conserved elements. They experimentally showed that, for several naturally occurring extended -10 promoters, the 5'-TRTG-3' motif is an important determinant for promoter activity. Eleven promoters were selected for further experimental study. Of those, the seven most active (aroF > ompF > envA > purFp1 > purEF > purMN > gyrA) were investigated regarding the contribution of the extended -10 motif by changing the 5'-TG-3' element. Promoters with poor matches to the -10 and -35 consensus hexamers are more dependent on the 5'-TG-3' motif, and this plays a similar role in different promoters. The dinucleotide at -17 and -16 in aroFp results in similar patterns of activity, suggesting that these bases play a similar role in different promoters |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC04467]|.

note: |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC26272]| identified two promoters (P1 and P2) upstream from the rpoS gene. However, |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC25005]| tested both promoters and reported that only one of them seemed to be functional (P2). Based on this evidence and the fact that P1 is too far upstream from the rpoS gene (920 bp), we only uploaded P2 as rpoSp to EcoCyc.

note: Porin regulation by the CpxA-CpxR system and by the EnvZ-OmpR system converges at the porin promoters |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC07052]|. The OmpR transcriptional factor cooperatively binds to the sites of the upstream regions from the ompFp promoter in a discontinuous \ galloping\ manner, as described by |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC07811]|. 554 promoter regions from Escherichia coli were aligned in order to analyze their sequence similarities. Mitchell et al. (2003) |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC04467]| focused on conservation, patterns, similarities, and differences between promoters with or without an extended -10 5'-TG-3' element and other conserved elements. They experimentally showed that, for several naturally occurring extended -10 promoters, the 5'-TRTG-3' motif is an important determinant for promoter activity. Eleven promoters were selected for further experimental study. Of those, the seven most active (aroF > ompF > envA > purFp1 > purEF > purMN > gyrA) were investigated for the contribution of the extended -10 motif by changing the 5'-TG-3' motif. Promoters with poor matches to the -10 and -35 consensus hexamers are more dependent on the 5'-TG-3' motif, and this plays a similar role on different promoters. The dinucleotide at -17 and -16 in aroFp results in similar patterns of activity, suggesting that these bases play a similar role on different promoters |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC04467]|.

note: The osmBp2 promoter is activated by potassium glutamate but only when σ<sup>S</sup> is used. σ<sup>70</sup> recognizes osmBp2 at low osmolarity. Only osmBp2 is induced by stationary phase at low osmolarity. The two promoters are active when both high osmolarity and stationary-phase signals are present simultaneously, but the osmBp2 activity is much greater than the osmBp1 activity.  osmBp2 was unambiguously characterized by |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC17190]| |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC06745]|.

note: The osmCp1 activity is normally independent of σ<sup>S</sup> and it leads to a basal level of expression during exponential phase. osmCp1 and osmCp2 overlap, but they appear to be independent of one another. The two promoters are both growth phase and osmotically regulated. They are sensitive to the action of the global regulators H-NS and Lrp, but the H-NS negative effect on these promoters could be indirect, because there are no putative binding sites of H-NS in the promoter region.

bindsSigmaFactor_name: RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoD, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoD, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoD
note: osmY is activated by potassium glutamate but only when σS is used. σ70 and σS recognize the osmYp at low osmolarity, but only σS activates this promoter at high osmolarity. This promoter is not a gearbox promoter. The osmY gene is positively regulated by RpoS in stationary phase and it is mainly controlled at the level of transcription |CITS: [ 11157932 ]|. The effect by RpoS is likely indirect and might be mediated by an intermediate regulator that itself is directly regulated by RpoS. Phadtare et al. found that CspC and CspE upregulate the expression of dps by regulating the expression of RpoS itself |CITS: [ 11157932 ]|.

bindsSigmaFactor_name: RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS
note: The operon otsAB is positively regulated by RpoS in stationary phase and is mainly controlled at the transcription level |CITS [RDBECOLIPRC08987], [RDBECOLIPRC26604]|. It is also osmotically regulated. Region 4 of the σ38 protein and the elements near the -35 DNA region are involved in triggering the response to high salt concentrations, which ensures the transcriptional activation of the otsBp2 promoter to counteract this physiological challenge |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC07520]|.

bindsSigmaFactor_name: RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS
note: The otsA promoter is an internal weak promoter, and it is within the otsB gene and 39 nt upstream from the otsA start codon. Upstream of otsB there is an inverted repeat, and a half-site of this repeat is also found in front of otsA. These may represent binding sites for a regulatory protein. The transcription of the otsBA operon is reduced when the rpoS gene is inactivated, but whether there is a σS-type interaction (direct or indirect) with the otsBA operon is not known.

note: Besides the σ54-dependent promoter that directs transcription, another σ38-dependent promoter seems to activate patA transcription. Both promoters initiate transcription at the same nucleotide. Under nitrogen-limited conditions, σ54 appears be dominant, and σ38 dominates in nitrogen excess |CITS:[ 23531166]|.

note: pcnBp4 (pS2) has at least two alternatives start sites, located in the region between positions -263 and -265 relative to the translation start codon, ATT |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12289]|. The pS2 sequence bears the C residue in the -10 box, which is crucial for selective recognition of the promoter dependent on Eσ<sup>S</sup> |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12289][RDBECOLIPRC04387]|. For the first time, activities have been reported for a σ<sup>S</sup>-dependent promoter (pcnBp4) that is inhibited by the stringent response factors ppGpp and DksA; these findings are based on both passive and active models |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12289]|.

note: Based on ChIp-chip analysis, it was shown that H-NS plays a role in pdeL expression |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC10718]|. Transcription directed across H-NS binding regions relieves H-NS-mediated (and H-NS/StpA-mediated) repression of promoters such as proVp3, pdeLp3, and appYp2, and there is a correlation between transcription across the H-NS-bound region and derepression where RNA polymerase is able to remodel the H-NS complex and/or dislodge H-NS from the DNA and thus relieve repression |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC18945]|.

note: The genes are expressed from two major promoters: Ppdh, which generates a 7.4-kb pdhR-lpdA readthrough transcript, and Plpd, which generates an independent 1.7-kb lpdA transcript. This could be an indirect effect mediated by ArcA activation.

note: proPp2 is central to the stationary-phase response. The sequence around the -10 region of the proPp2 promoter has similarity to those of σ70 promoters, but there is no resemblance in the -35 region. Fis and RpoS are two regulators that control different sets of genes in distinct stages of cellular growth and, in general, function antagonistically. However, proP gene expression at the proPp2 promoter is the unique case, with both regulators collaborating to achieve promoter activation. It is also the only case in which Fis functions as a class II transcription activator with its site centered at -41 (the proP regulatory region presents two sites for Fis, at -41 and -81 with respect to the +1 of transcriptional initiation). The ability of EσS to recognize nonoptimally placed and degenerated -35 elements enables EσS and Fis to control proP expression at proPp2|CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08806]|.

note: Expression of the proVWX operon is osmo-regulated and repressed by H-NS at low-osmolarity but not at high-osmolarity conditions |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC08982]|. Transcription directed across H-NS binding regions relieves H-NS-mediated (and H-NS/StpA-mediated) repression of promoters such as proVp3, pdeLp3, and appYp2, and there is a correlation between transcription across the H-NS-bound region and derepression where RNA polymerase is able to remodel the H-NS complex and/or dislodge H-NS from the DNA and thus relieve repression |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC18945]|.

note: ~90% of the ptsG mRNA is transcribed from a major promoter, P1 (ptsGp1) |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC29208]|. A third promoter in the region located between ptsGp1 and ptsGp2 was identified by in vitro transcription and by RNA polymerase footprinting techniques, as well as in vivo by S1 analysis and fusions with a lacZ reporter gene |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12261]|. It expresses a transcript antisense to ptsG that has characteristics more like a divergently expressed cryptic unstable transcript (CUT) than a prokaryotic sRNA |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12261]|. ptsGp1 was validated experimentally in aerobic conditions |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC15419]|.

note: 554 promoter regions from Escherichia coli were aligned in order to analyze their sequence similarities. Mitchell et al. (2003) |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC04467]| focused on conservation, patterns, similarities, and differences between promoters with or without an extended -10 5'-TG-3' element and other conserved elements. They experimentally showed that, for several naturally occurring extended -10 promoters, the 5'-TRTG-3' motif is an important determinant for promoter activity. Eleven promoters were selected for further experimental study. Of those, the seven most active (aroF > ompF > envA > purFp1 > purEF > purMN > gyrA) were investigated for the contribution of the extended -10 motif by changing the 5'-TG-3'. Promoters with poor matches to the -10 and -35 consensus hexamers are more dependent on the 5'-TG-3' motif and this plays a similar role on different promoters. The dinucleotide at -17 and -16 in aroFp results in similar patterns of activity, suggesting that these bases play a similar role on different promoters |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC04467]|.

note: pyrCp is primarily expressed under conditions of pyrimidine limitation, in which the CTP and GTP levels are low |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC04715]|. On the other hand, under conditions of pyrimidine excess, in which the CTP level is high and similar to that of GTP, pyrC is also expressed from another transcriptional start site, at a position two bases downstream of pyrCp. Despite that, pyrC transcripts form a regulatory hairpin at their 5' end, which blocks its own translational initiation, hence preventing translation of the pyrC cistron. Finally, pyrC is also expressed in a small percentage from other transcriptional start sites, located one base upstream and one position downstream of the pyrCp promoter |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC04715]|.

note: Production of RelA is controlled by two promoters, relAp1 and relAp2. relAp1 is a constitutive promoter, which is mainly responsible for RelA production during log phase. relAp2, which is fine-tuned by the global regulators CRP, H-NS, and RpoS, is induced temporarily at the transition state between the exponential growth and stationary phases. Both promoters are required for maximal accumulation of RelA during stationary phase. Although relAp2 expression is partially repressed by RpoS after mid-log phase, this negative effect could be due to the RNA polymerase competition |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08578]|. However, this could also be an indirect effect.

note: The RelA production is controlled by two promoters, relAp1 and relAp2. relAp1 is a constitutive promoter, which is mainly responsible for RelA production during log phase. relAp2, which is fine-tuned by the global regulators CRP, H-NS, and RpoS, is induced temporarily at the transition state between the exponential growth and stationary phases. Both promoters are required for maximal accumulation of RelA during stationary phase. There is a UP element-like sequence immediately after the -35 box of the relAp1 promoter which is essential for promoter activity (based on a mutation of the putative UP element) |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08578]|.

note: Two transcriptional start site (TSS) rnlB transcripts were also detected 123 and 124 bp upstream of the initiation codon |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12029]|. Expression of the rnlB promoter was much higher than from the rnlA promoter, indicating that high rnlB activity is important for cell viability, because RnlA in the absence of RnlB induces cell death |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12029]|. rnlB can be transcribed from rnlA promoters as polycistronic mRNA (there is not a transcription terminator-like sequence upstream of the rnlB promoter) and from its own promoter as monocistronic mRNA |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12029]|.

note: fabHp is subject to stringent control, and it is responsible for ~40% of all transcripts for fabH |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC27218]|. fabH has a GC-rich motif discriminator sequence between the -10 region and the start site, which is a characteristic feature of the stringently regulated promoter |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC27218]|. The fabH promoter is not only a contributor to its expression under all conditions, but also other activators might compensate to activate fabH expression when FadR is absent, and/or with basal expression of the fabHGD genes |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC15082]|.

bindsSigmaFactor_name: RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS
note: The σ70 and σS RNA polymerase subunits direct transcription from the rpoHp1 promoter in the exponential and stationary growth phases, respectively, and transcriptional start sites for the two holoenzymes differ by 1 nt |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC10629]|. Under nonstress conditions, the distal P1 promoter contributes to the majority of rpoH transcription |CITS:[ 3315851 ][7504905 ]|. There are four sigma factors (σ70, σS, σ54, and σ24) cooperatively controlling rpoH (σ32) gene expression, which provides high flexibility of the stress response |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC10629]|.

note: The rpsB promoter belongs to the extended -10 promoter class |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC10228]|. It comprises a TGTG extension upstream of the -10 hexamer TATAAA, a suboptimal -35 box, TTGGTG, and a GC-rich discriminator, GCGCGC, that separates the -10 element from the transcription start site and is reminiscent of a GC-rich "discriminator" typical for promoters under growth rate and stringent control |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC16388][RDBECOLIPRC10228]| and references therein|. The design of the rpsB promoter region is highly conserved in γ-proteobacteria |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC10228]|. Site-directed mutation on both the TGTG extension and the TTG element in the -35 region had effects on transcription, since they dramatically decreased the activity of the promoter |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC16388]|.

note: rpsUp2 has a sequence similar to that of a number of promoters under stringent control. Transcription initiation from rpsUDp2 and rpsUDp3 allows for greater readthrough at the internal terminator T2, thus increasing the relative ratio of dnaG and rpoD. rpsUp2 overlaps rpsUp3. It possible that another promoter with a transcriptional start site at positions 3210716/7/8 transcribes the rpsU-dnaG-rpoD operon, as determined by high-throughput screening of maps of promoters |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC20476]|.

note: The rraBp1 promoter overlaps an ArgR-binding site that represses the gene argI located upstream and in the opposite direction to the rraB gene |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC11375]|. However, the presence of arginine, which is the effector molecule of ArgR, does not affect rraB expression |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC11375]|. On the other hand, Khordursky et al. |CITS:[ 11027315]| reported that the expression of rraB is modulated by tryptophan starvation, but the rraBp2 promoter does not respond to tryptophan availability |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC11375]|. Another putative promoter was identified upstream of the rraBp1 promoter, but its activity was not observed in a primer extension analysis |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC11375]|. The sequence of the region containing the active (rraBp1) and inactive promoter is well conserved in the upstream region of rraB and is homologous to that in other bacteria, such as Shigella flexnerii, Salmonella enterica, and several strains of E. coli |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC11375]|. The rraBp2 promoter was not identified by |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC11375]|.

note: Keener J. and Nomura M. (1996). Regulation of Ribosome Synthesis, in: Neidhardt, F. (Editor in Chief) et al., E. coli and Salmonella. Cellular and Molecular Biology. ASM Press, Washington, D.C., p. 1417-1431. Although the organization and sequence of the seven major ribosomal RNA (rRNA) P1 promoters are highly conserved, the upstream region differs considerably in its regulation, with different transcription factor affinities for the individual upstream regions and strikingly different architectures of the resulting DNA-protein complexes that form with the individual rRNA operon upstream regions |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC06983]|. Based on studies of binding sites determined using gel shift and footprinting analyses with Lrp and H-NS regulator proteins, it was demonstrated that both proteins interact with obvious synergism in the repression of all seven E. coli rrn P1 promoter upstream regions; as a result, they help the efficient shutdown of rRNA synthesis. Likewise, both proteins could be a transient heteromer via a protein-protein interaction that interferes with the RNA polymerase, and this way it may alter the DNA of the upstream regions of all seven ribosomal P1 promoters |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC07284]|. The rrsAp1 is also recognized by σ32, which shows a -35 box, spacer, and -10 box, CGGAAT-14-CGCCAC, based on similarity to the consensus sequence of the set of known functional promoters for this σ factor, for which there is strong experimental evidence: high homology; score, 7.24; P-value, 2.35e05.

Although the organization and sequence of the seven major ribosomal RNA (rRNA) P1 promoters are highly conserved, the upstream region differs considerably in its regulation, with different transcription factor affinities for the individual upstream regions and strikingly different architectures of the resulting DNA-protein complexes that form with the individual rRNA operon upstream regions |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC06983]|. note: The σ32 holoenzyme can also recognize rrnBp1, at least in vitro |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC26700]|, but it has not been shown yet that this occurs in vivo. The transcription of the rrnBp1 promoter is reduced by guanosine tetraphosphate (ppGpp), which modifies the RNA polymerase. Perhaps this RNA polymerase forms an inactive promoter complex, as happens with the argTp promoter |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC06658]|. The presence of eight amino acids (alanine, glutamine, glutamic acid, isoleucine, leucine, methionine, serine, and valine) in the growth medium enhances the activity of the rrnBp1 promoter. |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC07863]| suggested that it is a result of the slow synthesis of one of the enzymes that produces ppGpp (the spoT gene product). Although the organization and sequence of the seven major ribosomal RNA (rRNA) P1 promoters are highly conserved, the upstream region differs considerably in its regulation, with different transcription factor affinities for the individual upstream regions and strikingly different architectures of the resulting DNA-protein complexes that form with the individual rRNA operon upstream regions |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC06983]|. Based on studies of binding sites with gel shift and footprinting with Lrp and H-NS regulator proteins, it was demonstrated that both proteins interact with obvious synergism in the repression of all seven E. coli rrn P1 promoter upstream regions; as a result, they help the efficient shutdown of rRNA synthesis. Likewise, both proteins could be a transient heteromer via a protein-protein interaction interfering with the RNA polymerase, and this way it may alter the DNA of the upstream regions of all seven ribosomal P1 promoters |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC07284]|. Many Lrp and H-NS sites were observed through a DNase I footprinting analysis in the rrnBp upstream region. Although no specific central positions were determined, the Lrp clusters between positions -20 and -90. It is important to note that the same sequence is strongly protected by an H-NS-DNA complex |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC07284]|. The rrsBp1 promoter is also recognized by σ32, which shows a -35 box, spacer, and -10 box, CGGAAT-14-CGCCAC, based on similarity to the consensus sequence of the set of known functional promoters for this σ factor, for which there is strong experimental evidence: high homology; score, 7.24; P-value, 2.35e05. Conserved region 3.2 of the primary σ70 factor (σ finger) negatively affects interactions of the σ70 RNAP holoenzyme with rrsBp1, by decreasing promoter complex stability and making it a target for repression by the stringent response factors DksA and ppGpp |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC19584]|. σ fingers play an important role in promoter complex formation, and this region is involved in the control of the activity of unstable promoters under changing growth conditions |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC19584]|.

note: Keener J. and Nomura M. (1996). Regulation of Ribosome Synthesis, in: Neidhardt, F. (Editor in Chief) et al., E. coli and Salmonella. Cellular and Molecular Biology. ASM Press, Washington, D.C., p. 1417-1431. Although the organization and sequence of the seven major ribosomal RNA (rRNA) P1 promoters are highly conserved, the upstream region differs considerably in its regulation, with different transcription factor affinities for the individual upstream regions and strikingly different architectures of the resulting DNA-protein complexes that form with the individual rRNA operon upstream regions |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC06983]|. The rrsCp1 promoter is also recognized by σ32, which shows a -35 box, spacer, and -10 box,CGGAAT-14-CGCCAC, based on similarity to the consensus sequence of the set of known functional promoters for this σ factor, for which there is strong experimental evidence: high homology; score, 7.24; P-value, 2.35e05.

bindsSigmaFactor_name: RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS
note: Transcription from the upstream rsdp1 promoter by Eσ<sup>38</sup> takes place only in the early stationary phase.  Under certain circumstances, the upstream sequence including the rsdp1 promoter exerts an inhibitory effect on the rsdp2 promoter function, because the deletion of the rsdp1 region results in an increase in transcription from the downstream rsdp2 promoter. The mechanism of inhibition by the upstream sequence remains unsolved.

bindsSigmaFactor_name: RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoD, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoD
note: The basal level of rsd transcription is maintained by using the downstream rsdp2 promoter recognized by Eσ70. On the basis of sequence similarity and unique expression patterns, such as the inverse relationship with the growth rate, the rsdp2 promoter can be classified as a member of the gearbox family of promoters, but it cannot be transcribed by Eσ38 in vivo or in vitro. Under certain circumstances, the upstream sequence including the rsdp1 promoter exerts an inhibitory effect on the rsdp2 function, because the deletion of the rsdp1 region results in an increase in transcription from the downstream rsdp2 promoter. The mechanism of inhibition by the upstream sequence remains unsolved.

note: The transcription initiation of rpoEp2 was determined by S1 mapping, and it was 4 nucleotides upstream from the site previously identified. This promoter was induced by zinc in a microarray analysis |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC07163]|. The NsrR transcriptional repressor inhibits the activity of the rpoEp2 promoter, but it is not known if this effect is direct or indirect |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC08960]|. This promoter appears to be induced in two phases after σE induction. It is induced during the first 5 minutes following σE induction, decreased from 5 to 10 minutes, induced from 10 to 15 minutes, and decreased from 15 to 20 minutes |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC20476]|.

note: Through inhibition of its own transcription, DksA creates a negative feedback loop that keeps its level constant in the cell |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC12919]|. DksA negative autoregulation occurs independently of CsrA regulation |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC12916]|.

note: Based on the one-round PCR product method, a novel site-directed mutagenesis method, it was determined that an srlA-driven expression system is a tool applicable for strong expression of foreign genes under cultivation conditions in LB medium without induction |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC19529]|. In addition, it was determined that the sequence adjacent to the start codon of the srlA gene is essential for high expression and that its promoter region is 100 bp. srlAp is a constitutive promoter in LB medium, and it is a sorbitol-enhanceable and glucose-, fructose-, galactose-, mannose-, xylose-, and arabinose- repressible promoter |CITS:[RDBECOLIPRC19529]|.

note: The promoter Pssp is similar to gearbox promoters. These promoters contain the gearbox element CGGCNAGTA. The sequence homology of Pssp with gearbox promoters and the growth rate dependence of sspA expression suggest that Pssp is a gearbox promoter |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC25918]|.

bindsSigmaFactor_name: RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoD, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoD
note: The activity of this promoter appears to be decreased in the presence of σE. It is repressed during the first 5 minutes following σE induction and decreased from 5 to 10 minutes and from 10 to 20 minutes after induction of the σ factor |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC20476]|. Transcription from the ssrSp1 and ssrSp2 promoters is regulated in a growth-phase-dependent manner |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC15146]|. In addition, transcription of ssrSp1 and ssrSp2 is feedback activated and feedback inhibited, respectively, and this feedback regulation is Fis dependent |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC15146]|. The differential feedback regulation could serve to integrate sigma factors, as well as providing a means for maintaining appropriate cellular concentrations of 6S RNA in response to environmental changes |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC15146]|.

bindsSigmaFactor_name: RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoH, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoH, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoH, RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoH
note: topAp1 is induced by heat shock and by hydrogen peroxide. The first induction is dependent of sigma32 and the last induction is dependent of Fis protein.No auxiliar factors are required for transcription of this promoter by the sigma32 holoenzyme, however this promoter is induced by the Fis protein, maybe this activation is sigma70-dependent, because it also resembles the core promoter recognized by this sigma factor.  The transcription of promoter topAp1 increases when FIS levels are low under the conditions of oxidative stress (hydrogen peroxide) and during the late exponential phase |CITS [RDBECOLIPRC08709], [RDBECOLIPRC27059]|. In contrast, high FIS levels of early exponential phase result in its repression. Recently, it had been demonstrated that this transcription factor overlaps the promoter topAp1 in a cooperative process, favoring the binding and the additional recruitment of molecules to form multiple complexes at the promoter topAp1 |CITS [RDBECOLIPRC08709]|.

note: Yu et al. showed in 2006 that transcription of yecF is highly dependent on alternative factor σF and can be transcribed by RNA polymerase σ28 in vitro |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08301]|. The sequence of this promoter has been defined, by computational analyses, from the consensus sequence of the σ28 (σF) promoters: TAAAGTTT in the -35 box and GCCGATAA in the -10 box |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08301]|. Therefore, we assigned a putative transcription start site for this promoter based on the observation that the majority of the σ28 promoters, determined experimentally, present an important -10 motif (5'-CGA-3') at the positions -12 to -10 and a distance of 6 nucleotides between the transcription start site and the -10 box |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08081], [RDBECOLIPRC08301], [RDBECOLIPRC02484]|.

note: The sequence of this promoter has been defined, by computational analyses, from the consensus sequence of the σ28 (σF) promoters: TAAAGTTT in the -35 box and GCCGATAA in the -10 box |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC02484]|. Therefore, we assigned a putative transcription start site for this promoter based on the observation that the majority of the σ28 promoters, determined experimentally, present an important -10 motif (5'-CGA-3') at the positions -12 to -10 and a distance of 6 nucleotides between the transcription start site and the -10 box |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08081], [RDBECOLIPRC08301], [RDBECOLIPRC02484]|. Park et al. showed in 2001 that transcription of ygbK is highly dependent on alternative factor σF |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC02484]|. The transcription expression level was examined in a fliA mutant background.

note: Even though of yjjBp was determined by Northern blotting, it was not shown in the sequences presented by |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC18434]|. However, they mentioned that it could be present at 660 bp upstream of the dnaT gene. The expression controlled by yjjBp can terminate at both terminators (t1 and t2) located downstream of the dnaC and yjjA genes, respectively. Transcription from yjjBp is weak compared to that from dnaTp and therefore its contribution to dnaT/dnaC expression is not significant |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC18434]|.

bindsSigmaFactor_name: RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA, RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA, RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA, RNA polymerase sigma factor FliA
note: The sequence of this promoter has been defined, by computational analyses, from the consensus sequence of the σ28 (σF) promoters: TAAAGTTT in the -35 box and GCCGATAA in the -10 box |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08301]|. Thus, we assigned a putative transcription start site for this promoter based on the observation that the majority of the σ28 promoters, determined experimentally, present an important -10 motif (5'-CGA-3') at the positions -12 to -10 and a distance of 6 nucleotides between the transcription start site and the -10 box |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08081], [RDBECOLIPRC08301], [RDBECOLIPRC02484]|. Yu et al. showed in 2006 that transcription of ynjH is highly dependent on alternative factor σF and can be transcribed by RNA polymerase σ28 in vitro |CITS: [RDBECOLIPRC08301]|.
